Langfang Hebei 065000 China New Catalytic Materials Engineering Research Center for Air Pollutant Control, Hebei province New Resin Material Technology Innovation Center, Langfang City Beichen Entrepreneurship Resin Materials Incorporated Co., Ltd., Langfang 065000, Hebei, China * Corresponding author. ABSTRACT Understanding the influence of HCl on the NH3-selective catalytic reduction reaction mechanism is crucial for designing highly efficient denitrification catalysts. The formation of chlorate species on the surface of the synthesized SbCeO x catalyst, induced by HCl, significantly enhances low-temperature activity, as evidenced by a 30% increase in NO conversion at 155 °C. Furthermore, it improves N2 selectivity at high temperatures, with a notable 17% increase observed at 405 °C. Both experimental results and density functional theory calculations confirm that chlorate species form at Ce sites. This formation facilitates the creation of oxygen vacancies, boosting the oxygen exchange capacity. It also increases NH3 adsorption at the Ce sites, promotes the formation of Sb-OH, and reduces competitive OH adsorption on these sites. Notably, compared with the reaction mechanism without HCl, the presence of chlorate species enhances NH3 adsorption and activation, which is vital for subsequent catalytic reactions. Graphical Abstract Can poisoning agents be thoroughly reform itself? HCl is oxidized to chlorate species on the surface of the SbCe catalyst, leading to the formation of Sb-OH. It could effectively alleviate the competitive adsorption of NH3 and OH at the Ce site. At the same time, the lattice oxygen activity was increased, unexpectedly enhancing the performance of NH3-SCR. Keywords NH3-selective catalytic reduction Chlorate species SbCeO x catalyst Density functional theory HCl 1 Introduction Incineration is an efficient technology for the domestic waste treatment, primarily due to its advantages in cleanliness and sanitation. Additionally, it reduces the volume of solid waste while enabling some energy recovery and reuse. However, secondary pollutants are generated during the incineration process, including heavy metals (Pb, Cd, Hg), acid gases (HCl, Cl2, HF, SO2, NO x ), particulate matter and dioxins. High concentrated NO and acid gas HCl can produce photochemical smog and acid rain [1]. Selective catalytic reduction of NO using NH3 as a reductant (NH3-SCR) is widely regarded as the most effective method for NO removal during domestic waste incineration [2]. The efficiency of this technology depends on the performance of the catalyst. Research indicates that a variety of metal oxides, including supported TiO2 and vanadium-based oxide catalysts, can be used for NH3-SCR reaction [3]. However, their performance is hindered by the presence of HCl gas, which leads to the formation of ammonium chloride or metal chloride species on the catalyst surfaces, thereby reducing active site density and SCR activity [4]. Our previous studies have focused on metal oxide catalysts, particularly their excellent anti-sulfur and anti-water properties [5]. Researchers have studied the effect of HCl on SCR catalysts, with several findings highlighting its significant inhibitory impact on the NH3-SCR reaction. Jiang et al. [6] studied the effect of HCl on the NH3-SCR reaction using a CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst. They reported that HCl leads to pore plugging, weakens the interaction between CeO2, MoO3, and TiO2, reduces the surface acidity of the catalyst, decreases the redox ability, and hinders the adsorption of NH3 species. At the same time, HCl disrupt the Ce3+/Ce4+ redox cycle, ultimately causing catalyst deactivation. Similarly, Guo et al. [7] explored the deactivation mechanism of Ce/TiO2 catalysts due to Cl. They proposed that the addition of Cl would reduce the adsorption capacity of NH3 and NO x species on the surface of catalysts at acid sites, which was the main reason for the reduction of catalyst activity caused by Cl. In contrast, some studies have found that HCl can actually enhance the catalytic activity of certain catalysts. This is attributed to the formation of additional acid sites on the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst when HCl is introduced. For example, Chan's research demonstrated that the introduction of HCl can form more acid sites on the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, and possibly adsorb on basic O2– sites to form new –OH groups. This, in turn, increases the adsorption capacity for NO and NH3 species on the catalyst surface, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity of the SCR process [8,9]. The effect of HCl on the NH3-SCR reaction requires further investigation. In this study, we designed a bimetallic composite oxide SbCeO x catalyst (SbCe catalyst) and measured its NH3-SCR activity to assess the impact of HCl. Using a combination of characterization techniques and density functional theory (DFT) calculation, we explored the relationship between the physicochemical properties of the catalysts and their catalytic performance. Additionally, we investigated the mechanism by which HCl influences the on SbCe catalyst in the NH3-SCR reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of SbCe catalyst A series of SbCe oxide catalysts with different Sb to Ce atomic ratios were prepared using the citric acid method. Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and Sb(CH3COO)3 were mixed in the specified ratios, with Sb(CH3COO)3 dissolved in ethylene glycol. Citric acid was then added, with the molar ratio of citric acid to the total metal components (the combined moles of Sb and Ce) set at 1.5. The mixture was stirred at 90 °C for 12 h to form a gel, which was subsequently dried at 120 °C for 24 h to produce a porous foam-like solid. This foamed solid was then calcined in air at 550 °C for 5 h, ground, and sieved to 40–60 mesh. The resulting oxide catalyst was designated as SbCe-ori. 2.2 HCl poisoning treatment To simulate the poisoning effect of acid gas HCl in a waste incineration plant, the catalyst with the best catalytic activity (SbCe-ori) was exposed to 50 ppm HCl for 12 h, simulating real-world deactivation conditions. The gas flow rate during the experiment was set to 100 mL/min. HCl treatment temperatures were set at 180, 280, and 380 °C to simulate different conditions. The three catalysts after HCl poisoning were labeled SbCe-180, SbCe-280, and SbCe-380, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction(XRD) measurement was carried out by using D/MAX-RB system under Cu Kα radiation. The XRD patterns were collected from 10° to 90° with the step size of 0.018° and 1 s per step. The BET surface area, pore volume and pore diameter were measured by N2 adsorption at –196 °C using a Quantachrome Autosorb AS-1 System. The surface species and surface valence changes on the catalyst were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) with monochromatic Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV) using an ESCALAB 250 XI electron spectrometer (Thermo Scientific, USA). The temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) experiments were conducted in a ﬁxed-bed quartz reactor. Specific test steps: (1) 100 mg sample particles were placed in a reaction tube and pretreated at 300 °C for 1 h in N2 atmosphere (30 mL/min) and then cooled down to 50 °C. (2) Introduced 10% NH3 and adsorbed at room temperature for 1h until adsorption saturation. (3) Stopped introducing NH3, purged with N2 for 30 min, and then raised the temperature from 50 to 900 °C at 10 °C/min in N2 atmosphere. At the same time, continuously record NH3 concentration and output it as TCD signal. The temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) measurements of hydrogen were obtained on a Micromeritics ChemiSorb 2720 device. The specific test steps are as follows: 100 mg catalyst was placed in the reaction tube, and the total flow rate of gas is 30 mL/min. Firstly, the sample was placed at 300 °C pretreated for 1 h in N2 atmosphere, and then cooled down to 50 °C. Then, 10% H2/Ar was introduced and the temperature was programmed from 50 to 700 °C at 10 °C/min. At the same time, H2 consumption was continuously recorded and output as TCD signal. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) were characterized by a Nicolet NEXUS 870 FT-IR spectrometer. The sample was pretreated at 500 °C for 1 h in flow of N2 (100 mL/min). 2.4 SCR activity test SCR reactions were performed in a fixed-bed, stainless steel reactor (inner diameter: 7.4 mm, vertical). The reaction gasses were 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, O2 (10 vol%); and balance N2. The total flow rate was 300 mL/min. The tested temperature range was 130–405 °C and the gas hour space velocity (GHSV) was controlled at 60000 h−1. The outlet gas concentrations were measured by a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FT-IR, Bruker TENSOR II) equipped with a liquid N2-cooled MCT detector and a gas cell. The activity data were collected after 50 min at each temperature. The NO removal efficiency and N2 selectivity were calculated as follows: (1) NO removal efficiency = NO in - NO out NO in × 100 % (2) N 2 selectivity = ( 1 - NO 2 out + 2 N 2 O out NO in + NH 3 in - NO out - NH 3 out ) × 100 % where, NOin is the concentration of NO at the reaction inlet, NH3in is the concentration of NH3 at the reaction inlet, NOout is the concentration of NO at the reaction outlet, NO2out is the concentration of NO2 at the reaction outlet, N2Oout is the concentration of N2O at the reaction outlet, NH3out is the concentration of NH3 at the reaction outlet. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NH3-SCR activity The NH3-SCR performance and N2 selectivity were examined with a series of SbCe catalysts synthesized at different atomic ratios (Sb:Ce = 1, 1.3, 1.5). Fig. 1(a) shows the NO conversion as a function of temperature in the range of 130–405 °C. The results showed that the Sb:Ce = 1.3:1 catalyst exhibited the best low-temperature SCR activity across the widest active temperature window. The conversion of NO reached 93% at the temperature range of 180–355 °C. Fig. 1(b) shows the N2 selectivity of the SbCe catalysts. At low temperature (130-180 °C), the N2 selectivity was negatively correlated with the Sb:Ce ratio. The highest N2 selectivity achieved was 97% on the Sb:Ce = 1:1 catalyst at a temperature of 150 °C. At temperatures above 200 °C, similar values of N2 selectivity were obtained at different Sb:Ce ratios, achieving an average N2 selectivity of 80%. In the actual waste incineration flue gas environment, the catalyst is exposed to the atmosphere containing HCl. To simulate this, the catalyst (Sb:Ce = 1.3:1, SbCe-ori) was treated in a flowing 50 ppm HCl atmosphere at different temperatures (180, 280, and 380 °C, labeled SbCe-180, SbCe-280 and SbCe-380 respectively) for 12 h. Afterwards, the NH3-SCR activity and N2 selectivity were measured. The results, shown inFigs. 1(c) and (d), indicate that HCl treatment at 280 °C yielded the most significant improvement. Compared to the untreated catalyst, the SbCe-280 sample exhibited a remarkable phenomenon: the NO conversion increased dramatically from 66% to 96% at a low temperature of 150 °C, along with a notable increase in N2 selectivity across the entire temperature range. Such an improvement in both NO conversion and N2 selectivity has not been observed with other catalysts in the NH3-SCR process. Considering that catalysts are continuously exposed to HCl erosion during reactions under practical conditions, the duration of SbCe poisoning under HCl atmospheres was extended to 24 h, and the resulting sample was designated as SbCe-280-24. As shown in the Fig. 1, the test results indicate that the NO x conversion rate of SbCe-280-24 is similar to that of SbCe-280 and both are higher than that of SbCe-ori. This suggests that the SbCe catalyst exhibits relatively stable SCR catalytic activity. In practical applications, the cyclic use of catalysts is of great significance for waste incineration treatment. Therefore, we conducted cyclic usage tests on SbCe-280. As shown in Fig. S7, it was found that with the increase in the number of tests, the catalytic activity of SbCe-280 in the low-temperature range improved significantly, increasing from 29% to approximately 58%. This may be due to the full exposure of the active catalytic sites after high-temperature activation, resulting in enhanced NO x decomposition capability at low temperatures. After three cycles of testing, the NO x conversion rate of the catalyst slightly decreased. Additionally, water resistance tests were conducted on SbCe-ori and SbCe-280 catalysts at 280 °C. As shown in Fig. S9, the catalytic activity remained stable at 100% for a certain period of time. 3.2 Properties of the framework and structure The XRD patterns of the SbCe catalyst before and after HCl treatment at different temperatures are shown in Fig. 2(a) . Diffraction peaks corresponding to CeO2 (PDF-#78-0694) were identifiable in all the catalysts. No SbOx related peaks were observed, likely due to the small particle size. The morphology of SbCe and SbCe-280 samples was visualized by TEM, revealing that the catalyst particles were uniformly distributed with no significant particle agglomeration.Figs. 2(e) and (h) show that the lattice fringe spacing d remained consistent at 0.32 nm for all samples, corresponding to the (111) plane of CeO2. This indicates that the catalyst structure remained unchanged after HCl treatment, which is consistent with the XRD results. Elemental mapping of the SbCe-280 catalyst, as shown in Fig. 2(b), revealed that O, Ce, Sb, and Cl were uniformly distributed across randomly selected areas of the sample. Combined with the XRD results, this indicated that the active catalyst species were incorporated into the catalyst bulk rather than accumulating as oxides on the surface. Furthermore, the ICP results showed that the atomic molar ratio of Sb to Ce was 1.29:1, closely matching to the input ratio of 1.3:1. Compared to the SbCe-ori and SbCe-280 samples, the 24 h HCl treatment did indeed result in a decrease in diffraction peak intensity accompanied by peak broadening, indicating that the crystal structure underwent some degree of change. This change typically suggests a reduction in crystal particle size or the introduction of defects in the crystal structure, leading to a decrease in crystallinity. However, the characteristic peaks in the diffraction patterns showed minimal change with increasing HCl treatment time, indicating that the catalyst structure was not completely destroyed. Table 1 provides the specific surface area, pore volume and average pore size of the fresh catalyst (SbCe-ori) and catalysts treated with HCl at different temperatures (SbCe-180, SbCe-280, SbCe-380). The adsorption isotherms are shown in Fig. S1 and Fig. S2. The results indicate that the average pore size of the catalysts treated at 180 and 280 °C in HCl is slightly lower than that of the fresh catalyst and the catalysts treated at 380 °C. Notably, the SbCe-280 catalyst exhibits the smallest average pore size of 4.11 nm compared to the other samples. Combining the XPS results shown later, this could be due to the formation of chlorate species within the pores after the introduction of HCl. However, at 380 °C, the temperature is high enough to decompose the chlorate species, resulting in the recovery of the pore size for the SbCe-380 catalyst. In addition, the small pore size and large specific surface area of the SbCe-280 catalyst may contribute to its excellent catalytic activity [9]. The valence states of the surface elements of different catalysts were characterized by XPS (Fig. 3 ). The surface chemical composition and valence obtained in these XPS spectra are listed in the supporting information(Table S1). The XPS Cl 2p spectrum is shown in Fig. 3(a). With the peak at a binding energy of 206.7 eV assigned to Cl5+. This suggests the oxidation of the adsorbed HCl to produce the chlorate species during the HCl treatment. At mild temperatures, the chlorate species could be deposited on the catalyst and block the pores. However, at high temperatures (380 °C), the chlorate species are speculated to thermally decompose and evaporate [10], as indicated by the lower Cl5+ content in XPS. The evolution of the Cl XPS results was consistent with the BET result. As the number of cyclic tests for SbCe-280 increased, the XPS Cl 2p spectra, shown in Fig. S8, and the state of chlorate ions on the catalyst surface, summarized in Table S3, indicate a decrease in the proportion of chlorate ions. This suggests that the chlorate ions began to decompose, although the extent of decomposition was relatively small, and the ions remained in a relatively stable state. As shown in Fig. 3(b), the highest Oads/(Oads+Olatt) value was achieved with the fresh SbCe catalyst. This value decreased after treatment with HCl for 12 h, suggesting that the surface adsorbed oxygen and a small part of the surface lattice oxygen reacted with HCl to form chlorate species. When the surface lattice oxygen participated in the HCl oxidation process, it could promote the formation of oxygen vacancies, resulting in defective oxygen, which can promote the SCR reaction process [11]. These may be the reasons why the SbCe-280 catalyst offered excellent low-temperature SCR catalytic activity and N2 selectivity. The Ce 3d XPS spectrum is shown in Fig. 3(c). With respect to Ce4+, the content of the Ce3+ was significantly increased after the HCl treatment, which is associated with the increase of the oxygen vacancies. Studies have shown that Ce3+ could promote NO oxidation by increasing the adsorption of NO [12]. Moreover, the electron transfer between Ce3+ and Ce4+ also contributes to the oxygen exchange process, which might be one of the reasons why the low-temperature SCR activity of the SbCe-280 catalyst has been effectively improved. The Sb 3d XPS is shown in Fig. 3(d). With respect to Sb5+, the concentration of the Sb3+ species increased after the HCl treatment, due to the increase in oxygen vacancy. Meanwhile, the binding energies of the Sb species were reduced after the HCl treatment at 180 and 280 °C. Hence, some Sb5+ species were reduced to Sb3+ species. However, at a higher temperature of 380 °C, the decomposition of chlorate changed the coordination environment, resulting in an increased binding energy. Two redox pairs of Ce4+/Ce3+ and Sb5+/Sb3+ were formed on the catalyst to facilitate the redox cycles involving the redox reaction of “Sb5+ + 2Ce3+ ↔ Sb3+ + 2Ce4+“ [13], which is essential for the low-temperature SCR catalytic reaction on the SbCe-280 catalyst. 3.3 Properties of acid sites and active sites 3.3.1 NH3-TPD results NH3-TPD was used to determine the number and strength of acid sites on the catalyst surface. The results are shown in Fig. 4(a) and summarized in Table S2. Desorption peaks with temperatures below 200 °C correspond to physically adsorbed NH3 or NH4 +* species on weak Brönsted acid sites. Peaks between 200–450 °C indicate NH4 +* species on strong Brönsted acid sites, and those above 450 °C represent NH3* species adsorbed on Lewis acid sites [14–17]. As shown in the Fig. 4, the NH3 desorption peaks at 171, 147, 123, and 136 °C are attributed to physically adsorbed NH3 or NH4 +* species on weak Brönsted acid sites. The peaks at 283, 338, 292, 344, and 345 °C are attributed to NH4 +* species on strong Brönsted acid sites, and the peaks at 538, 611, 578, 821, 855, 861, and 846 °C are attributed to NH3* species adsorbed on Lewis acid sites. Consequently, the total number of acid sites significantly increased after treatment with HCl, leading to excellent high-temperature selectivity. 3.3.2 H2-TPR results The oxidation-reduction activity of the catalyst plays a vital role in the NH3-SCR reaction. H2-TPR was used to detect the changes in the redox performance of the catalysts before and after HCl treatment, as illustrated in Fig. 4(b). All four catalysts exhibit a major reduction peak in the range of 504–545 °C, which can be attributed to the reduction of Ce4+ → Ce3+ and Sb5+ → Sb3+ [18]. After HCl treatment, these reduction peaks shifted to the lower temperature region, indicating that the redox activity of the catalyst was enhanced. 3.4 In Situ DRIFTS To establish the molecular mechanism of NO catalytic reduction by NH3, the changes in characteristic vibrational peaks during the reaction between NH3, NO, and O2 were recorded using in-situ DRIFTS at 50–350 °C, as shown inFigs. 5(a) and (b) . At room temperature, the stretching vibration peak of the asymmetric N–H bond from the NH3 species was observed at 3367 cm–1. The peak at 3248 cm–1 corresponds to the N–H stretch from NH3 species adsorbed on Lewis acid sites [19], while the peaks at 1749 and 1416–1400 cm–1 were assigned to the asymmetric bending vibrations of NH4 + species at Brönsted acid sites [20]. At 50 °C, peaks at 1330 and 1315 cm-1 were observed, which are associated with the NH3 species coordinated on Lewis acid sites [21]. As the temperature increased, the adsorbed NH3 species underwent dehydrogenation, converting to –NH2 species, indicated by the peak at 1270 cm–1 [22]. The accumulation and consumption of –NH2 species reached equilibrium at 200 °C for the as-prepared SbCe catalyst, while this temperature was reduced to 150 °C for the SbCe-280 catalyst. In addition, on the as-prepared SbCe catalyst, the intensities of the characteristic peaks for NH3 species on Lewis acid sites and NH4 + species on Brönsted acid sites reached their maximum at 200 °C. In contrast, the SbCe-280 catalyst showed this maximum at 150 °C. These results indicate that the adsorption and activation of NH3 species were more efficient on the SbCe-280 catalyst, which is crucial for low-temperature catalysis. Meanwhile, the peaks at 1537 and 1542 cm–1, associated with bidentate nitrate species [23], were detected at 100 °C due to NO oxidation. The intensities of these peaks increased with rising temperatures, suggesting that NO oxidation forms bidentate nitrate species on the catalyst surface, which need activation at 100 °C. However, when the temperature exceed 250 °C, the bidentate nitrate peaks began to decrease, likely due to their reaction with NH3, desorption from the surface, or self-decomposition. The transient in-situ DRIFTS experiment results were illustrated in Figs. S3 and S4. It can be concluded that the pre-adsorbed NH3 species react with the gaseous NO species but can not react with the adsorbed NO. Therefore, the reaction follows the Eley-Rideal mechanism. 3.5 The DFT results The influence of different valence states of Cl on SbCe catalysis was investigated with DFT calculations.Figs. 6(a) and (b) show the slab models of the optimized structures of the CeO2 and SbCe catalysts. The construction process for these models is described in detail in the supporting information (1.5 DFT calculation details). The DFT calculations showed that the formation energy of oxygen vacancies was reduced from 4.33 eV (Fig. 6(c)) to 1.94 eV (Fig. 6(d)) after doping Sb atoms in CeO2, which indicated that the oxygen vacancies were more likely to be formed on the SbCe catalyst. In addition, the doping of Sb atoms also significantly increased the contribution of oxygen states in the band near the Fermi level (E F) (Fig. 6(i)). Thus, the covalent bonds of Sb–O and Ce–O were significantly enhanced [24], which is important for proton-electron transferring [25] and lattice oxygen activation [26]. The adsorption of HCl or ClO3 – ions on the SbCe catalyst was also investigated. The adsorbed HCl was not stable on the SbCe catalyst. It was decomposed into H+ and Cl– ions (Fig. 6(e)), which were adsorbed on the lattice oxygen and Ce atoms, respectively. Besides, the oxygen vacancy formation energy was reduced to 1.38 eV (Fig. 6(f)), which confirmed that the adsorption of Cl– ions promoted the formation of surface oxygen vacancies. However, the center of the O 2p-band decreased from –3.45 to –3.61 eV. Moreover, with further decrease in the oxygen vacancy formation energy, the mobility of oxygen would reduce [27], resulting in a decrease in the oxygen exchange kinetics. This would cause the poisoning of the catalyst by the accumulating surface HCl. XPS results showed that HCl could be oxidized to ClO3 – ions on the SbCe catalyst. The calculation found that ClO3 – was favourably adsorbed on the Ce atoms (Fig. 6(g)). Compared with the fresh SbCe catalyst, the oxygen vacancy formation energy was slightly reduced to 1.82 eV, Fig. 6(h), after the adsorption of ClO3 –, while the O 2p still had a significant contribution near the Fermi level, as shown in Fig. 6(i). On the other hand, the center of the O 2p-band rose to –3.06 eV, indicating that the adsorption of ClO3 – ions promoted the formation of oxygen vacancies with increased oxygen exchange capacity. This can explain why the adsorption of HCl inhibited the SCR catalytic activity, while the formation of ClO3 – ions on the surface will increase the SCR activity. To study the acidic characteristics of the Sb-doped CeO2 catalyst, the adsorption of NH3 on different acidic sites was calculated.Figs. 7(a)–(d) show the NH3 adsorption configurations on Ce and Sb sites for both the as-prepared SbCe catalyst and the ClO3 –-adsorbed SbCe catalyst. The calculations showed that NH3 was more likely to be adsorbed on the Ce site. After ClO3 – ions were adsorbed, the NH3 adsorption energy increased from –0.94 eV (Fig. 7(a)) to –1.48 eV (Fig. 7(b)). The in-situ infrared spectroscopy study revealed that the number of Brönsted acid sites on the catalyst surface increased after HCl treatment, which may be associated with the formation of surface hydroxyl groups. The calculated OH adsorption on the Ce and Sb sites on the as-prepared and ClO3 --adsorbed SbCe catalysts is shown inFigs. 7(e)–(f). On the fresh SbCe catalyst, OH was more likely to be adsorbed on the Ce site, which competes with the adsorption of NH3. Hence, a large amount of adsorbed OH is not conducive to the activation of NH3. However, with ClO3 – adsorption, OH is more likely to be adsorbed on the Sb site, since the adsorption energy of OH on the Ce site is higher than that on the Sb catalyst. This shows that the formation of chlorate during the HCl treatment can not only inhibit the adsorption of OH on the Ce site to avoid competing NH3 adsorption but also promote the adsorption of OH on the Sb site. The calculation also confirms that the formed Sb-OH site is a type of Brönsted acid site, which can couple with the NH3 species. The stronger acidity would help to activate NH3 and avoid the oxidative decomposition of NH3 species. The formation of Sb-OH after HCl treatment could be another reason for the high SCR activity at low temperatures and improved N2 selectivity at high temperatures. 3.6 Discussion Based on the experimental and theoretical results, the reaction process for NH3-SCR on the surface of the HCl treated SbCe catalyst is proposed in Scheme 1 . During the HCl treatment, HCl reacts with adsorbed oxygen and surface lattice oxygen, oxidizing HCl and forming chlorate species on Ce sites, as confirmed by XPS and DFT results. Simultaneously, oxygen vacancies (□) are created as lattice oxygen consumed during Cl- oxidation. This defective surface promotes NH3 adsorption on Ce sites, which would react with residual lattice oxygen to form the amide species (–NH2) on the Ce sites, while generating additional oxygen vacancies and hydroxyl species on the Sb sites. The amide species would react with NO to form the critical intermediates of NH2NO [28], which decompose to produce N2. Meanwhile, the adsorption of the ClO3 - on Ce3+ sites helps for the formation of the hydroxyl group on the Sb sites, which stabilised NH3 in the form of sb3+-O-NH4 + to reserve the source of NH3 on the surface. Therefore, the acidity of Brönsted acid sites was responsible for the adsorption of NH3, which was consistent with the results of in-situ infrared and NH3-TPD. Gaseous NO could also be oxidized to produce NO2 [29]. Then the species at the Brönsted acid sites would react with the NO2 to generate N2 and H2O offering a much improved N2 selectivity. 4 Conclusions In our study, we observed an intriguing phenomenon: the enhanced efficacy of HCl treatment on SbCe catalysts in facilitating the NH3-SCR reaction, which contradicts conventional expectations. Our investigation revealed that treating the SbCe catalyst with HCl at 280 °C resulted in a 30% increase in NO conversion at 155 °C and a 17% improvement in N2 selectivity at 405 °C. Spectroscopic analyses and Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations shed light on the impact of HCl treatment and delineated the underlying mechanism of the NH3-SCR reaction. Notably, the formation of chlorate species on Ce sites was observed, which led to a significant increase in the formation of oxygen vacancies and enhanced oxygen exchange capabilities. This treatment also optimized NH3 adsorption while effectively suppressing the competitive adsorption of OH on Ce sites, leading to the formation of Sb-OH. Consequently, the presence of chlorate species significantly facilitated the involvement of lattice oxygen in the reaction, improving the adsorption and activation of NH3 molecules. This research offers valuable insights into how HCl treatment promotes the formation of active sites through oxygen vacancies, enhancing the NH3-SCR process in waste incineration tail gases. coredata.dc:description: ABSTRACT Understanding the influence of HCl on the NH3-selective catalytic reduction reaction mechanism is crucial for designing highly efficient denitrification catalysts. The formation of chlorate species on the surface of the synthesized SbCeO x catalyst, induced by HCl, significantly enhances low-temperature activity, as evidenced by a 30% increase in NO conversion at 155 °C. Furthermore, it improves N2 selectivity at high temperatures, with a notable 17% increase observed at 405 °C. Both experimental results and density functional theory calculations confirm that chlorate species form at Ce sites. This formation facilitates the creation of oxygen vacancies, boosting the oxygen exchange capacity. It also increases NH3 adsorption at the Ce sites, promotes the formation of Sb-OH, and reduces competitive OH adsorption on these sites. Notably, compared with the reaction mechanism without HCl, the presence of chlorate species enhances NH3 adsorption and activation, which is vital for subsequent catalytic reactions.

coredata.dc:title: An unexpected reversal: The smart performance of hydrogen chloride on SbCe catalysts for NH3-SCR reaction
